channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Silvio Berlusconi Died. But for Her, the ‘Bunga Bunga’ Scandal Lives On.
item.description: The woman at the center of revelations of bacchanals at the former Italian prime minister’s villa is still fighting a court case, and a negative public image, 14 years later.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Davide Monteleone for The New York Times
item.media:description: “He messed up my life,” Karima el-Mahroug says of Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian prime minister who died last year.

item.title: Can the Government Get People to Have More Babies?
item.description: Japan has been trying to boost its fertility rate for 30 years. Now the rest of the rich world is, too.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich

item.title: Jokes and Offbeat Auctions for the Troops: Standup Comedy Sweeps Ukraine
item.description: Even as the conflict with Russia grinds on, a new generation of comics in Ukraine is trying to make people laugh — and raise money for the war effort.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anton Tymoshenko performing at a stand-up comedy show in July in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Russian Strikes on Ukrainian Ports Target Civilian Shipping
item.description: With the strikes in the Odesa region, Russia appears to be trying again to prevent Ukraine from exporting grain, harming its economy and pushing up world prices.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Port of Odesa in March. Russia has intensified its strikes on the region recently.

item.title: Ladakh’s Local Hero Wants India to Pay Attention to His People
item.description: The activist Sonam Wangchuk is leading protests to demand more autonomy for India’s remote Ladakh region, which shares borders with China and Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Tauseef Mustafa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Sonam Wangchuk, an activist from Ladakh, is leading protests to demand more control over how the region is used and governed.

item.title: Secret Documents Show Hamas Tried to Persuade Iran to Join Its Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: The Times reviewed the minutes of 10 meetings among Hamas’s top leaders. The records show the militant group avoided several escalations since 2021 to falsely imply it had been deterred — while seeking Iranian support for a major attack.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Adam Rasgon and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A house in Kibbutz Kfar Aza, Israel, last December that was among those attacked on Oct. 7, 2023.

item.title: Canada Tightens Immigration Policy And Leaves Thousands in Limbo
item.description: Canada has long had one of the world’s most open immigration policies. Now, faced with a growing popular backlash, it’s changing the rules.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Willms
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: International students and others line up for busses, in Brampton, Canada, on Monday. Canada’s post-pandemic experiment at large-scale import of foreign students and temporary workers is heading for a rapid overhaul.

item.title: Alex Salmond, Scotland’s Former First Minister, Dies at 69
item.description: Mr. Salmond led the Scottish National Party twice, guiding it from a fringe political group into a powerful electoral force in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Salmond in Glasgow in 2021. Keir Starmer, the prime minister of Britain, called him a “monumental figure of Scottish and U.K. politics.”

item.title: How South Korea’s Dogs Became Members of the Family
item.description: They have become pampered family members in South Korea, which has the world’s lowest birthrate and where much of the population lives alone.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Chang W. Lee
item.media:description: O Hanna, a teacher, at Dogkingabout, a “total dog care center” in Seoul.

item.title: Rise of the Dragons: Fire-Breathing Drones Duel in Ukraine
item.description: Drones are getting another new twist: Soldiers attach canisters to them to create weapons capable of spitting out molten metal that burns at 4,400 degrees.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian drone operators preparing to test a new drone last month in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Israeli Strikes on Northern Gaza Kill at Least 20, Aid Workers Say
item.description: Israel’s military said it was “operating with great force” against Hamas and allied groups and issued new evacuation orders, as it also continued its campaign in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.media:credit: Omar Al-Qattaa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mourning on Saturday over the bodies of Palestinian relatives killed overnight in the Jabaliya area of the northern Gaza Strip.

item.title: China Vows to Unleash More Borrowing to Spur Economy and Strengthen Banks
item.description: The finance minister said Beijing would sell bonds to supplement spending and help banks but did not detail how much.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Consumer spending in Shanghai and elsewhere in China has weakened as confidence in the economy has plummeted. Apartment prices and sales of luxury goods have plunged.

item.title: Israeli Jets Pummel Hezbollah Targets in Southern Lebanon
item.description: Sirens sounded in northern Israel, warning of incoming fire from Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Mohammad Zaatari/Associated Press
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings on a commercial street on Sunday hit overnight by Israeli airstrikes, in Nabatieh town, south Lebanon.

item.title: How Palestinians Are Roadblocked in the West Bank
item.description: Driving in the Israeli-occupied West Bank is an incredibly different experience depending on who you are. Ben Hubbard, international correspondent for The New York Times, rode along on two bus trips, one for Israelis, the other for Palestinians, that tell a story of separate and unequal roadways.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Rebecca Suner and James Surdam

item.title: Boot Found at Everest Could Be From Sandy Irvine, Who Vanished 100 Years Ago
item.description: When Sandy Irvine went on a pioneering expedition to Mount Everest’s summit in 1924, he and his partner vanished. The recent discovery may shed light on the ill-fated adventure.
item.dc:creator: Hank Sanders
item.media:credit: Noel E. Odell/Royal Geographical Society, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The last known image taken of George Mallory, left, and Sandy Irvine. The two men vanished while trying to be the first to reach the summit at Mount Everest in 1924.

item.title: Fitch Ratings Issues Warning About France’s Finances
item.description: A rating agency’s warning about the country’s ballooning debt comes as the prime minister tries to push an austerity budget through a divided Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Teresa Suarez/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Fitch Ratings warned that it could lower France’s sovereign credit rating if the government’s budget plans fall apart.

item.title: Love Lessons
item.description: The editor of the long-running Modern Love column reflects on two decades of working with people’s deeply personal stories.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Jones

item.title: In British Columbia, a Political Party’s Collapse Echoes an Earlier Election
item.description: The end of a coalition of Conservatives and Liberals over 70 years ago led to a surprising election result and reshaped the province’s politics.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

item.title: Boris Johnson Makes a Case for Trump’s Return, and Perhaps, His Own
item.description: In his memoir, “Unleashed,” the former prime minister is “optimistic” about the possibility that Donald J. Trump could regain the White House.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The epigraph for Boris Johnson’s memoir is “Hasta la vista, baby,” an Arnold Schwarzenegger line from a “Terminator” film.

item.title: Is Israel’s Invasion of Lebanon Legal? Here’s What International Law Says.
item.description: Explaining the issues of sovereignty, self-defense and humanitarian safeguards.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath on Friday of an overnight strike in the Ras el-Nabaa neighborhood in central Beirut that killed at least 22 people and wounded more than 100.

item.title: Lebanon’s Leader Calls on U.N. for Cease-Fire as Beirut Searches for Airstrike Survivors
item.description: Rescuers dug through rubble in Beirut as the caretaker prime minister implored the United Nations to adopt a resolution calling for an “immediate” truce between Israel and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Euan Ward, Liam Stack, Ephrat Livni and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath in Ras el-Nabaa, in central Beirut, on Friday after overnight Israeli airstrikes killed at least 22 people and wounded more than 100.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich, U.S. Journalist Imprisoned in Russia, Will Publish a Memoir
item.description: The memoir, which will cover his time in prison and Russia’s move toward autocracy, will be published by Crown, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter and Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich was freed as part of a complex prisoner swap after 16 months in a Russian prison.

item.title: Northern Lights Animate Night Skies Around the Globe: Photos
item.description: An outburst from elevated solar activity created conditions on Thursday that kept people’s eyes glued to evening views all over the Northern Hemisphere.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Jane Barlow/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The light of the aurora borealis shining brightly over what are known as the Kissing Trees, near the town of Kinghorn, in Fife, Scotland.

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize Is Awarded to Nihon Hidankyo For Its Efforts to Rid of Nuclear Weapons
item.description: Toshiyuki Mimaki, the chairman of Nihon Hidankyo, which was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, said his foremost wish was to “please abolish nuclear weapons while we are alive.”
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Hisako Ueno and Kiuko Notoya
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: United States Army
item.media:description: The devastation of Hiroshima in the aftermath of the atomic bombing in 1945, in a photo released by the United States government.

item.title: Israeli and U.S. Defense Ministers Discuss Israel’s Expanding Military Operations in Mideast
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III spoke with his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, on Thursday, the Pentagon said.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Kevin Lamarque/Reuters
item.media:description: Defense Minister Yoav Gallant of Israel at the Pentagon in June. Mr. Gallant and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had been scheduled to meet in Washington this week, but the visit was postponed.

item.title: Lebanon’s Leader Calls for U.N. Resolution on an ‘Immediate’ Cease-Fire
item.description: It was the latest attempt by Najib Mikati’s embattled government to bring an end to the violence that has killed thousands and displaced nearly one million.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Lebanese Prime Minister's Press
item.media:description: Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister, Najib Mikati, speaking on Friday, in a handout photo provided by the Lebanese prime minister’s press office.

item.title: The Premier League’s Fight With Manchester City Won’t End Well for Anyone
item.description: A decision about rules that left both sides claiming victory revealed the broken reality of the world’s richest competition.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Lee Smith/REUTERS, via Action Images, via Reuters
item.media:description: Erling Haaland after reading City’s latest legal filing.

item.title: North Korea Accuses the South of Sending Drones Over Pyongyang
item.description: Pyongyang threatened military action if the provocations continued, while the South advised its angry neighbor not to act “rashly.”
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Jung Yeon-Je/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: South Korean reconnaissance drones during a ceremony earlier this month at Seoul Air Base in Seongnam, South Korea.

item.title: U.S. Aims to Revive Failed U.N. Plan for Israel-Lebanon War
item.description: Biden administration officials are discussing whether a United Nations plan that ended Israel’s last invasion of Lebanon can be built to last this time.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Israeli airstrikes in southern Lebanon on Monday. A 2006 U.N. resolution was meant to withdraw Israeli and Hezbollah forces from the area.

item.title: For Atomic Bomb Survivors, Nobel Peace Prize Is a Bittersweet Victory
item.description: Many survivors of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki attacks have dedicated their lives to campaigning for nuclear disarmament. Their mission has grown more urgent as the number of living witnesses to the bombings has dwindled.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Hisako Ueno and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Kyodo, via Reuters
item.media:description: Shigemitsu Tanaka, a member of Nihon Hidankyo, reacting in Nagasaki, Japan, after the Nobel announcement on Friday.

item.title: Israel Orders Gazans to Leave the North, but Most Are Staying Put
item.description: A woman in a town surrounded by Israeli troops said she and her family stayed away from the windows and prayed for relief: “That’s how we survive these dark days.”
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Omar Al-Qattaa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Smoke rising as seen from a shelter in Jabaliya, in northern Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: Who Are Nihon Hidankyo and the Hibakusha of Japan?
item.description: Those who lived through the nuclear attacks of 1945 have dedicated their lives to recounting their experiences of loss and the physical and emotional toll.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Kyodo, via Reuters
item.media:description: Nagasaki Peace Park in southwestern Japan on Friday.

item.title: Ukrainian Journalist Viktoria Roshchina Dies in Russian Captivity, Ukraine Says
item.description: Viktoria Roshchina, a 27-year-old reporter, had been detained by the Russian authorities after reporting from occupied territories in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: via Hromadske
item.media:description: Viktoria Roshchina, 27, speaking in a broadcast interview for Hromadske’s television channel. She reported at great risk from areas in southern Ukraine to document the Russian occupation there.

item.title: Rescuers Search for Survivors After Strikes Hit Central Beirut
item.description: Lebanese officials said at least 22 people were killed in an Israeli attack that reduced one of the capital city’s central intersections to a ruin.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: After a strike in Beirut, Lebanon, on Friday.

item.title: In Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley, a Lone Gas Station Is a Lifeline
item.description: Thousands have fled the town of Baalbek amid a barrage of Israeli airstrikes. For those who remain, Ali Jawad’s business is a critical piece of an informal safety net.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sánchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abdul Latif fills a customer’s car at Ali Jawad’s gas station, in Baalbek, Lebanon this week.

item.title: Conflict Between Israel and Iran Adds to Oil Market Volatility
item.description: Israel and Iran are fighting at a time when prices are under pressure because of weak demand in China and concerns about oversupply.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Fatemeh Bahrami/Anadolu, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Isfahan is home to one of the largest refineries in Iran.

item.title: How The Times Investigated Indian Political Ties to Labor Abuse in the Sugar Industry
item.description: Western companies such as Coca-Cola buy sugar from fields where workers suffer abuses. But the country has labor laws. Where was the government?
item.dc:creator: Megha Rajagopalan
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers in a sugar cane field last December in Pandharpur, India.

item.title: What Flying in a Wind Tunnel Reveals About Birds
item.description: Some birds migrate thousands of miles every autumn. How exactly do they manage it? Scientists built a flight chamber to find out.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Ian Willms
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: A western sandpiper taking flight in the wind tunnel of Western University’s Advanced Facility for Avian Research in Ontario.

item.title: Why Lawmakers Ignore Human Rights Abuses in India’s Sugar Fields
item.description: Politicians run most of the mills in the state of Maharashtra. They deny or downplay evidence of coerced hysterectomies, debt bondage and child labor in the fields.
item.dc:creator: Megha Rajagopalan and Qadri Inzamam
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jaywant Sugars Ltd. in Karad, India, before the start of the sugar season, in September.

item.title: A Woman Won South Korea’s First Literature Nobel. That Says a Lot.
item.description: While Han Kang’s victory was celebrated as a crowning cultural achievement for her country, her work also represents a form of rebellion against its culture.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Han Kang, shown in 2016, is both the first South Korean and the first Asian woman to win the Nobel Prize in Literature.

item.title: ‘Relentless’ Israeli Attacks on Gaza Medical Workers Are War Crime, U.N. Panel Says
item.description: The report, which does not have the force of law, found that the Israeli military had engaged in deliberate assaults on hospitals and other health care providers.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Omar Al-Qattaa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A medical worker near a destroyed hospital in Gaza City in September.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Florida Hurricane Kills at Least 7
item.description: Plus, Han Kang receives the Nobel Prize in Literature.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of an apartment complex in Clearwater, Fla., were rescued from floodwaters.

item.title: Airstrikes in Beirut Kill at Least 22 and Injure Over 100, Lebanon Says
item.description: The attack, for which Lebanese officials blamed Israel, appeared to be the deadliest in the Lebanese capital in more than a year of fighting between the Israeli military and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Ephrat Livni and Aric Toler
item.media:credit: Bilal Hussein/Associated Press
item.media:description: Several buildings in central Beirut were hit by airstrikes on Thursday.

item.title: The Forecast: 832 Degrees in Brazil? Weather App Glitch Sends Extreme Weather to New Heights
item.description: No, it will not actually reach 832 degrees in Brazil’s capital this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Sara Ruberg
item.media:credit: Andy Rain/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The BBC apologized on Thursday for its inaccurate weather predictions that showed wild winds and insanely high temperatures for cities around the world.

item.title: Who Are the U.N. Peacekeepers at Lebanon-Israel Border?
item.description: Established to maintain peace in southern Lebanon, the UNIFIL forces have been increasingly caught in the middle of the Israeli-Hezbollah war.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Italian member of the U.N. peacekeepers in Lebanon in July.

item.title: Israel’s Security Cabinet Met to Discuss Response to Iran Attack
item.description: The cabinet was expected to authorize initiating a retaliatory attack, officials said. They didn’t make their decision public.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Amir Cohen/Reuters
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier inspects the remains of an Iranian ballistic missile in southern Israel on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Parliament Approves Biggest Tax Increase of War to Support the Army
item.description: The authorities are resorting to a politically unpopular move as they scramble to raise funds for the grueling military effort against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firing from a position near Selydove, eastern Ukraine, this month. The tax rise is likely to hit hard in the country, where people have already seen their economic well-being plummet because of the war.

item.title: Israel Fired on Peacekeepers in Lebanon, U.N. Says
item.description: Israel was behind the attack, Lebanon said, and it came on the same day that the U.N. said Israeli forces had fired on its peacekeepers, an episode that drew international condemnation.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Liam Stack, Aric Toler and Michael Levenson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Bilal Hussein/Associated Press
item.media:description: Carrying a body amid destroyed buildings in central Beirut that Lebanon said had been hit by an Israeli airstrike on Thursday night.

item.title: In One Photo: Lebanon’s Dahiya Area After Strikes
item.description: Once lively and densely packed, the area on the edges of Beirut that was hit by an Israeli strike is now vacant.
item.dc:creator: David Guttenfelder
item.media:description: In One Image Rubble, and Defiance By David Guttenfelder

item.title: Why the NBA Is Making Abu Dhabi Its Middle East Hub
item.description: The league has held preseason games in the United Arab Emirates for three years. It says the impact has been positive, but others say it’s helping a repressive regime.
item.dc:creator: Tania Ganguli and Hilary Swift
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Jaden Springer with the ball in the second game, played at Etihad Arena on Sunday.

item.title: Black Girls Hike Founder Seeks to Make U.K. Hiking More Inclusive
item.description: Motivated by the racial disparity she saw on trails, Rhiane Fatinikun founded Black Girls Hike to make Britain’s countryside more inclusive.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rhiane Fatinikun, the founder of Black Girls Hike, on Ingleborough, a peak in the Yorkshire Dales National Park in England, after climbing it with a group of hikers this year.

item.title: Faced With Regional Setbacks, India Flexes Its New Economic Muscle
item.description: Tapping into a fast-growing economy, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been offering financial help to India’s neighbors as he tries to counter China’s influence.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Adnan Abidi/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, right, with President Mohamed Muizzu of the Maldives in New Delhi on Monday. Mr. Muizzu called India, which offered more than $750 million in aid, “a key partner.”

item.title: Nima Rinji Sherpa Becomes Youngest Climber to Summit 14 Highest Mountains
item.description: Nima Rinji Sherpa’s achievement highlights the role of Sherpas in an activity where they shoulder much of the risk but receive little glory.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: 14 Peaks Expedition, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The mountaineer Nima Rinji Sherpa at Annapurna Base Camp in Nepal in March.

item.title: Latest WWF Wildlife Survey Points to ‘Alarming’ Declines
item.description: The results from an important ongoing assessment look grim. But the survey is often misunderstood.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the Colombian Amazon. The Living Planet Index found a reduction of 73 percent in the average size of monitored wildlife populations worldwide from 1970 to 2020.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Florida Braces for Hurricane Milton
item.description: Plus, literature’s greatest prize.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cape Coral, Fla., yesterday.

item.title: Nearly a Million in Lebanon Flee Israel-Hezbollah Conflict, U.N. Says
item.description: A week into the ground war between Israel and Hezbollah, shelters in Lebanon are filling up beyond capacity, humanitarian officials warned.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Aryn Baker, Ben Hubbard and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Ammar Awad/Reuters
item.media:description: Emergency personnel at work after a fire at a residential building caused by a rocket fired from Lebanon, in Kiryat Shmona, northern Israel, on Wednesday.

item.title: Democracy Struggles in an Era of Mistrust and Upheaval
item.description: The Athens Democracy Forum last week explored the world’s schisms in the face of threats from technology and shifts in the world order.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Nikolas Kokovlis/NurPhoto, via AP
item.media:description: Achilles Tsaltas, the president of the Democracy & Culture Foundation, which organizes the Athens Democracy Forum, at the 2024 event last week.
